Title: Eyeing Sumatera through the color of its textile and culinary
Affiliations: School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Purbasari, M., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Rahardja, A., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Luzar, L.C., School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Analysis of cultural color is an approach to better understand color from cultural stand point, unlike other color studies which looks at the psychological aspect of color. Johannes Itten’s theory of color serves as a thinking base in this study. The theory is reflected in the cultures of Indonesia, and represented by island of Sumatera (Aceh DA, Medan, Padang, Bengkulu, Palembang, and Lampung). The scope of the subject matters is limited to traditional textile products such as traditional costumes and bridal apparel, and culinary. The textile products are chosen because they become reflection of a culture whose place is close to society, and its color become the society’s own identity. The research method is qualitative, consist of literature study, experts interviews (historians and artists), and visiting cultural centers especially the ones associated with textile and culinary product. The result of the study is presented in the form of morphological matrix on cultural color. The matrix is supported with arguments and classroom experiments which allows students to use, cultivate, and maximize the method of applying color in visual communication to achieve harmony and contrast. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
